1078141622972440576.text: 23/ what do you think about the strategies and commodization strategies? Any to add?

1078141470245146624.text: 22/ some of this will be sacrilege but the projects are better that the 99% will care more concretely about benefits than principles.

1078141270533464064.text: 21/ What will be the result? Does “security” matter, does “decentralization” matter, does father coin matter? Do merchants and “services and goods” economy matter or financial economy matter more?

1078138488325758976.text: 20/ The history of tech has been to commoditize the complement and to bootstrap one side of the network.

1078123250519928833.text: 19/ All of these view the world very differently, but problem with currencies is to "bribe" the consumer as the credit cards did. The problem with the smart contract platforms is "is security a given with Proof of Authority and Proof of Stake" and what layers is a commodity?

1078122768841924608.text: 18/ This ledgerless approach sacrifices global queryability and composability for lower fees, and onboarding real life institutions with assets tied to physical locations (country currencies) enabling counter party risk to be assessed with institutions.

1078121571238043648.text: 17/ The other approach is a bridge to the existing world which is Ripple and Stellars approach. This takes existing economic entities which can settle, and issues IOU notes on chain.

1078121075978907648.text: 16/ The "economic abstraction" on one hand adds to the liquidity of Eth. On the other hand you could argue that you don't need to hold Eth to gain access to the network. Just hold BTC.

1078120858348969984.text: 15/ Then there is an implicit strategy of "economic abstraction" which allows BTC to access to decentralized finance infrastructure of Maker Dao and compound finance. This is a double edge sword.

1078120555314700289.text: 14/ EOS is taking an end to end approach having apps pay for centralized services and having user readable names and user experiences that people are used to. This basically says that decentralization doesn't matter that much, and parity to current usage is more important.

1078120165940682753.text: 13/ Many are "embracing and extending" Webassembly to extend the opcodes to their use cases taking advantage of the broader open source.

1078119938294829056.text: 12/ Consensus engines assume upper layers are more commodity. Hashgraph and others are simply adopting EVM and making dapps portable over.

1078119524040302592.text: 11/ There is a strategy of "enveloping" and "embracing and extending" Substrate/Parity and Cosmos assume that everything will be a proof of authority and that security will be solved, and therefore their VM and opcodes will commoditize the base layer the consensus layer.

1078118848929255424.text: 10/ The competition got more interesting as the smart contract platforms got underway with consensus, op codes (VM), programming languages, smart contract security.

1078118454534664196.text: 9/ Most of these currencies state that they are competing against money, but in reality they are competing against "Credit." What most people think of money these days is simply Credit.

1078117494261374978.text: 8/ The early use cases of credit take into account both sides of the market places, provide an easy user experience physical cards and manually bootstrapped these accounts with marketing and sales. Will a decentralized currency simply bootstrap distribution?

1078116986373038081.text: 7/ The problem with these currencies is that they are cloud currencies that focus on debit use cases. If you see the early use cases of credit card companies including Bank of America Card, Diner Club. They provide ease of use, billing consolidation for consumers as well.

1078116665898881024.text: 6/ Privacy leads to fungibility, # of coins leads to scarcity, and people compete over "fees" which is transferability. All privacy like ring signatures, bulletproofs, and zk-snarks is in context of these currencies.

1078116159382142979.text: 5/ These have minimal upper layers and compete on traditional currency measures: fungibility, scarcity, durability, and transferability. You see this with announcements and conversations about the tech.

1078115380676026368.text: 4/ The "medium of exchange" started with competing for "services and goods" economy with Litecoin, Bitcoin Cash, Dash. The implicit strategy is that they are trying to bootstrap the supply and then the demand will come.

1078114703161737216.text: 3/ The beginning was Bitcoin as peer to peer cash. Private key = value (bearer shares), security as a competition. The implicit assumption was exchanging, but in fact it became the lead "collectible."

1078113914733260800.text: 2/ First we have to see the fundamentals view of money, the layers of crypto, publication vs validation, verticals, and the relationship between different chains.

1075333801197404160.text: 11/ Any other comments on Spotify? What was the difference in their choices that made them differentiated in the beginning? Feel free to add below.

1075333454194241536.text: 10/ In theory, technology is commoditized but in practice it's not. This was the start of the Spotify user centric music, where playlist became the foundation for recommendations and a music subscription that everyone used.

1075332792588869632.text: 9/ Instead, Spotify used a peer to peer architecture with a servers as a fall back, and experimented if the latency was dramatically better. It was. That was the foundation: desktop client, personal playlists, licensed music. This was different than generic wisdom you heard.

1075332033465978882.text: 8/ iTunes cost too much as it scaled, buying 99 cents is fine, but people wanted free or a bundle, cloud web experience didn't work as promised the latency was too high, the user experience needed to be personalized iTunes was simply a store.

1075331172874493952.text: 7/ So this was the context of Spotify, competing against iTunes, conventional wisdom says just deploy it to the cloud, but it neglected the following problems.

1075330698624557056.text: 6/ iTunes/iPod was 10x better because 1000 times the songs, no skipping vs CD players, fully integrated to a store, different purchase experience, ability for mobility.

1075330394260684801.text: 5/ Conventional wisdom of streaming like Real Networks, neglected bandwidth latency problems, licensing, and end device user experience. The MP3 experience created the latent demand, but couldn't full capture it.

1075330086717587456.text: 4/ Then iTunes and iPod came out, it used conventional license, a la carte pricing, and a hardware/software bundle to drive distribution.

1075329755724042240.text: 3/ The conventional view was that things are shifting toward the cloud, do a client/server architecture, get some license and then done.

1074652797080137728.text: 36/ In conclusion, non productive assets (ERC20) in a quantitative easing environment is causing a deleveraging on Eth/Btc, there are no governments to bail these currencies out, how will this go? No idea.

1074652231994105856.text: 35/ There were inherent aspects that came out: private property for digital assets (NFTs), securities platform (maker dao, harbor), enabling counter party risk offchain (WBTC, Harbor). You see the early signs of native systems. What else in your opinion has worked?

1074651573219966976.text: 34/ The question of the dot com boom was how does this medium inherently enable the use case. There was the same attempts: private internets (like private blockchains), big companies trying internet (Eth enterprise), company vs company internets (blockchain consortiums)

1074650874553741312.text: 33/ Stellar and its approach of issuing IOU promissory notes with the counter party being real entities is decent as well, but the vision is more quickly being done by Revolut and the Neo banking revolution.

1074650455651835904.text: 32/ While there were many things that didn't go right the bright points came out: Eth as securities platform (yes I said it), domain specific validation and the supremacy of focus (btc/monero), maker dao as a stable token (although with non productive erc20 tokens).

1074649870592552960.text: 31/ If Google+ can't take down Facebook, why should http://Status.IM ? The bigger question is that if your dapp is hoppled by metamask wallet requirement, low responsiveness (due to synching with eth), and don't have a distribution strategy, how will it succeed?

1074649466542678016.text: 30/ The final issue is that may of the applications on Eth competed directly with technology giants. The funding, team, distribution, and UX were all insufficient.

1074649104150454272.text: 29/ Some people have pointed out that Btc failed in its goals, I would argue that it's simply on its way. In network effects, "single player mode" comes before multiplayer mode. Single player mode of being a collectible and simply surviving is sufficient:https://twitter.com/MustStopMurad/status/1022169639386836992 …

1074648758074388480.text: 28/ The points about Btc are endlessly debated and if anything else medium, twitter, and others will increase the network effects of Btc.https://medium.com/s/story/bitcoins-social-contract-1f8b05ee24a9 …

1074648213817303041.text: 27/ We also see with Bitcoin Cash ABC/SV that they forked the code but couldn't fork the social consensus. With Btc after surviving the tumult of 2017. This is social consensus about the properties of a technology, not generalized "community."

1074647332686389248.text: 26/ We still have the Stellar/Ripple experiment running. The distributed ledger architecture seems to be a proof of authority architecture. I know the crypto communities perspective on them but the jury is still out.

1074646675011092481.text: 25/ On the other hand, generalized computation seems to have a key use case around decentralized finance, but the problem is the layer 2 projects of Eth still use non productive assets, and by continually locking up CDPs with non productive assets increases the leverage of Eth.

1074646322941231104.text: 24/ The progression of computation has been subsuming previous eras, whereas it's very likely that once a protocol is good enough for its area it can maintain its lead: bitcoin, handshake dns, and monero.

1074645894199418880.text: 23/ The good things is that we see the value of domain specific validation and general composability. VCs think that generalized validation will subsume the "calculator" Bitcoin. This is only true in areas where people don't highly value security and decentralization.

1074645319990808577.text: 22/ It's true that Eth has maximum composability but that leads to: bloated chain 1TB+, lack of full node decentralization, unscalable TPS, lack of data chain synched with main chain, and all of this will be solved in 2020 with Serenity.

1074644440617181185.text: 21/ People just realized in late 2018 that the "build it and they will come" may not work with http://Status.im  laying people off, ConsenSys laying people off, ETCDev shutting down. This is the unwinding of a leveraged bubble that's unwinding right now.

1074643866911944710.text: 20/ This caused confusion, many teams like ConsenSys, http://Status.IM , and others thought Vitalik was very smart and awaited the flippening. Correspondingly, lots of teams held their treasuries in Eth and just relied on "belief" because "belief" is what provides bids.

1074643259161501702.text: 19/ This is also seen with "belief." Many people believed in Eth as an Ethos and Btc as an Ethos. Btc maximalist laughed with glee as the ICO boom crashed not realizing that the key use case for Btc during this boom was speculating with non productive financial assets.

1074642930906947585.text: 18/ There is a common perception that blockchain teams are a commodity and everyone is coming out with scalable blockchains. The refrain is "community matters." Yes it does but if technology team fail more often than not it causes the collapse of the community.

1074642391942991873.text: 17/ One can argue that technology is necessary but not sufficient, and community is sufficient but not necessary. Simply put, belief and having other speculators with you in telegram and reddit is not enough to prevent a currency from going down.

1074642024136097793.text: 16/ In one moment the faith was shattered on the technical team, and it dropped further than most coins. At one point it was valued almost at $20B. The same thing with IOTA with its tangle system, hand rolled cryptography, and toxic founders. It's not clear whether it'll survive.

1074641254812655616.text: 15/ The both had good reddit/discord/telegram group but did it matter? Neo famously failed when one of its server failed, indicating that their consensus a round robin system didn't work.https://twitter.com/ercwl/status/970294228122263552 …

1074640849957474304.text: 14/ The problem is that this was tested in two main cases: NEO, IOTA. One was the Chinese Ethereum and the other was a new crypto chain based on no fees. Both ostensibly was loved by the community for its promises: regional SC and fast and no fees.

1074640441843294218.text: 13/ One of the underlying beliefs is that because money is a shared delusion, one can simply belief a money into existence if enough people belief. People regularly cited Yuval Noah Harari. The assumption is the majority rules and as long as the majority votes, it's fine.

1074639922756284416.text: 12/ In this process we had a couple of hypothesis tested: "community vs technology", "minority vs majority rule", "belief vs demand of currency", "financial economy not services and goods", "bloated state vs UTXO", "general composability/validation vs domain specific validation"

1074639287566696448.text: 11/ Famously in the financial crisis of 2008 Bears and Lehman welt bankrupt through the deleveraging process and this is causing the increasing sell off of Eth and Btc. Yes, I said it: btc was used to buy tokens too and this cascading sell off.

1074638720203153408.text: 10/ The trend of increasing your BTC/ETH wealth through the cycle of ETH -> token -> more ETH ended up not working, people over leveraged, and caused personal solvency issues that kept on cascading downward.

1074638434722037760.text: 9/ The issue with investing in tokens is that unlike the 2001 to 2008 bubble, this isn't even real estate, the utility tokens were non productive assets that returned no associated cash flow, so as soon as there were no more new buyers then things started crashing.

1074638127367639043.text: 8/ In most cases, the shadow banking is propped up by returns and solvency. I invest my money into this "productive asset" and then I get this money back, I use this money to leverage up and invest in another "productive asset" and so forth.

1074637880860004352.text: 7/ With every bull market in the normal economy, you'll have a "shadow banking" economy where people go into risky assets in search of returns. This ended up being the utility token market. This was the subprime market in 2001 to 2008, which spectacularly crashed in end of 2008.

1074637387966398464.text: 6/ The approach that ended up working (causing the bull market of 2017) Ethereum coincided with the big bull stock market 2017 and ended almost simultaneously when the central bank (U.S.) started raising interest rates and reducing quantitative easing.

1074636788113788928.text: 5/ As people pondered what to do there were a couple of different approaches: colored coins (asset validation on top of bitcoin), distributed ledger (ripple and stellar) issuing IOU/Promissory notes with banks, and smart contract (account/balance with generalized state ledger).

1074636274328309760.text: 4/ The underlying assumption with this strategy was that if enough merchants adopt it, then you simply airdrop to consumers. The problem was that 'sound money' was competing with credit, and effectively credit cards.

1074635898107650049.text: 3/ The problem was how do you distribute this as a global currency. There are two economies: the services & goods economy and the financial economy. People took the currency and tried to add merchants to bootstrap the demand. Coinbase started with this, and instead pivoted.

1074635277375819783.text: 2/ The beginning was the ultimate OG Bitcoin with Nakamoto Consensus. The underlying assumptions were private key = value (bearer shares), security at all cost, domain specific validation (UTXO validation), single player mode (store of value), and a community around collectible.

1074033275927187458.text: 10/ Most schools are focused on short term results (A's) vs understanding the chains of habit, character and the long term compound effects of both and using meta thinking to constantly adjust this.

1074033033211248641.text: 9/ Most of school is centered around progressive levels of abstraction, whereas the usefulness of real life is meta thinking applying abstract thinking to examine oneself, environment, and adjusting OODA loop style.

1074032682777088000.text: 8/ This is a structural advantage because these are things that kids and people don't do naturally, the meta thinking of what will dominate is something schools, life, and no matter what experience you have will ever teach you.

1074032400890544128.text: 7/ Most people think linearly and use lists to examine pros and cons assuming that everything is equally weighted. Typically one or two things dominate. Example is choosing first job favor geography and industry vs early salary whereas most people weight all of this similar.

1074031954276814848.text: 6/ These decisions make people favor "short termism", "value decisions through pro and con lists", "buy high, sell low", "fomo".

1074029128922394627.text: 4/ Traditionally the way to mitigate this is to teach discipline, the value of time, accomplishing more and more things based on a fixed schedule. This assumes a more predictable/industrialized society.  Linear vs nonlinear.

1036492219417542656.text: 12/ So at a time where physically (infrastructure) the united states is slowing down, we have to turn to books to understand what is possible and to allow people to mimetically imitate "non conformism" "internal locus of control" "strategic thinking"

1036491598534766592.text: 11/ Non conformity is so embedded in success that in finance there are greek letters for it: beta and alpha. Alpha is what you do that the herd doesn't do, beta is what the herd does. What in your life do you agree simply because of social consensus? Probably quite a lot.

1036491270066237440.text: 10/ Nonconformist people tend to come from trauma, read the bios of Lincoln, Clinton, @elonmusk , steve jobs, and there are all hints of childhood trauma and conflict. Could optimizing for a happy childhood get you to the top 10%, but not all of the way there?

1036490785301123072.text: 9/ The converse side of Mimetic theory is that fundamentally to be successful you have to be non conformist, you have to do the things that the herd isn't doing, not desiring, fight against your internal biological need to imitate.

1036490422955204610.text: 8/ This aspect of teaching "high agency" to be normal is the reason why silicon valley exists and why startup school exists. It teaches us that successful people are just like you and I and life is path dependent, partially dependent on the values and culture that we internalize.

1036490086001598464.text: 7/ I noticed this aspect among the kids of the Kennedy's and other bios where the kid's were taught to be mimetic of the qualities of the attributes of "high agency" people as @EricRWeinstein defines it.

1036489647789096960.text: 6/ Instead of applying this toward envy, is there another way to use this toward imitation of attributes we care about? A conversation with @emersonspartz in which he mentioned that his dad made him read bios of successful people growing up.
